turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Little more gas.  Ease it up.  Hold on- minor setback.  Now you feel confident, right?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Now, go into second.  Little more gas... Yeah!  You can get  this whole problem.  Now, maybe you downshift to first?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: This is so noble.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Well no, it's not noble, but it's a good aid to your lesson.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Let's get outta here.  You want to?

turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Are you comfortable?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yes.  Are you shaking?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: You're shaking.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.text: You're cold.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I don't think I am.

turns.text: Then why are you shaking?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I don't know.  I'm happy.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Here are some blankets.  This is a good song, this is a really good song.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Check your mail tomorrow.  I sent you a letter, a letter.

turns.text: Your letter came yesterday.

turns.text: It did?

turns.text: Uh-huh.  It was wonderful.

turns.text: Why didn't you tell me?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: It was wonderful.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I've never sent a letter like that, you know?  I mean, I felt like I wanted to tell you something, but I didn't put it in the letter, and I didn't say it, but I want to say it now, I'm not sure if I should say it, you know, 'cause people always say it and don't mean it, but I think that I mean it, so, um, I just wanted to tell you...

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: No, we don't have to say it.

turns.text: How do you know what I'm going to say?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I don't know what you're going to say, but I think that...

turns.text: I was just going to tell you that I love you.  I said it.

turns.text: What?  This is a good level, isn't it?

turns.text: Say what?

turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.text: You need to study?

turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Okay, how much time do you need?  I mean, you know, I mean you'll be leaving in a little while, so that's answered some questions.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: We'll see.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Okay.  It's good knowing this.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yeah, uh-huh.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Okay, what did we just decide?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: We decided...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: 'Cause I'm worried, did you just break up with me?

turns.text: No, no.

turns.text: I think that we should stop going out on dates.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I feel like a dick.  You must think I'm a dick.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: No, I don't, I don't.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Yeah you do.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Lloyd, we shared the most intimate thing two people can share.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: You shared it with a dick.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: No I didn't.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Is this because of your dad?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: No.

turns.text: Did you tell anybody?

turns.text: Just my dad.

turns.text: You told your dad?

turns.text: You have Corey and DC.  I have my dad.

turns.text: What, I'm sorry I said that.  Forget I said it, it's what I thought I meant, but forget it.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Lloyd, I love you, okay?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: What is that?  What are you doing with your hands?  Talk to me, you're talking like that girl Sheila.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Don't be mean, this is hard for me too.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Then don't do it.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Oh shit.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: My father's guilty.  He lied to me, he lied to everybody.  I just left home... I need you.

turns.text: You do?

turns.text: Everything else means nothing to me.  If I hurt you again, I'll die.

turns.text: I love you.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I love you.  How many more times do I have to say it?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: One more time would be nice.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I love you.  Please, I love you.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I'm fine.

turns.text: Okay, good, this is all very noble.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.text: Okay.

turns.text: Okay, I'll give here the message.

turns.text: What?

turns.text: She's really pretty great, isn't she?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Hello Lloyd.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Hello.  Heard about that graduation present.  Really quite a car. Look, I know you're busy, you don't' have to retain me, but you can trust me.  I'll tell you a couple of things about myself, I'm nineteen, been overseas for a couple of semesters, but now I'm back.  I'm an athlete, so I rarely drink.  Kickboxing.  You heard of kickboxing, sport of the future?  Don 'The Dragon' Wilson, Lenny [?] merciless, one of the champions of the sport?  I can see by your face, no.  My point is, you can relax because your daughter will be safe with me for the next seven to eight hours.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Fine Lloyd.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: How ya doing?  Is she around?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Yeah.  Honey?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Thanks Lloyd.

turns.text: How do you pay for one of those?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well, we pay for the [?].  That guy didn't want to part with it, a little matter of nine thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Yeah Lloyd.  What are your plans for the future?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Spend as much time as possible with Diane before she leaves.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Seriously, Lloyd.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I'm totally and completely serious.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: No, really.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: You mean like career?  Uh, I don't know.  I've, I've thought about this quite a bit sir, and I'd have to say considering what's waiting out there for me, I don't want to sell anything, buy anything or process anything as a career.  I don't want to sell anything bought or processed, or buy anything sold or processed, or... process anything sold, bought or processed, or repair anything sold, bought or processed, you know, as a career I don't want to do that.  So, uh, my father's in the army, he wants me to join, but I can't work for that corporation, so what I've been doing lately is kickboxing, which is really a, uh, new sport, but I think it's got a good future.  As far as career longevity goes, I don't really know, because, you know, you can't really tell.  Your training sticks  as a fighter, you know, but it's no good, you know, you have to be great, but I can't really tell if I'm great until I've had a couple of pro fights. But I haven't been knocked out yet.  I don't know, I can't figure it all out tonight sir, I'm going to hang with your daughter.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Hi, Lloyd.  This is my eighth and final call...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Go ahead, pick it up if you want.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I just wanted to say that I've thought about everything, and I've decided something.  I'm going to give you another chance.  Maybe no one's listening, or maybe your father's listening.  Mr Court, if you're listening to this, hello, how are you?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: She wouldn't get out of the car.  I brought her all the way here, she said she was going to come here, and she wouldn't get out of the car.  But I thought that is was important, that she come to see you, because I know that if you go somewhere and you don't deal with your family stuff, then you're just gonna, she's gonna, um...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Are you going to England with her Lloyd?

turns.speaker: LLOYD

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Are you?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Am I going?  Am I going to England?  I've thought about this quite a bit, and I've realised what I probably should do is just carve out a goal for my future and find out what I wanna do with my life, do all the stuff that I've been avoiding in a big way. I mean, Diane and I can wait for each other, right?  What's she gonna... she's gonna run off with some English guy?  There's no way.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well Lloyd, I admire you for not hitching a ride.  You know, my daughter's a lot different to you.

turns.text: I know.

turns.text: She's very successful.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I know

turns.text: Very talented.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You're not a permanent part of her life.  You're a distraction.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I'm the distraction that's going to England with her sir.  Are you alright sir?  Are you okay?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I'm incarcerated, Lloyd!  I don't deserve to lose my daughter over this.  I don't deserve to have you as my go-between.  And I can't for the life of me figure out how she could choose to champion in mediocrity the way she flirts around you.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: The gentleman thinks a mistake's been made.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: My plant manager is somewhere on this train. If it leaves with him on it, it'll disrupt production and the Armaments Board will want to know why.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: You know what, you'd like her.

turns.speaker: EMILIE
turns.text: Oskar, please -

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: What -

turns.speaker: EMILIE
turns.text: I don't have to like her just because you do.  It doesn't work that way.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: You would, though.  That's what I'm saying.

turns.speaker: EMILIE
turns.text: It's not a charade, all this?

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: A charade?  How could it be a charade?

turns.speaker: EMILIE
turns.text: Luck.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: War.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: EMILIE
turns.text: I feel like an old-fashioned couple. It feels good.

turns.speaker: EMILIE
turns.text: Should I stay?

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: It's a beautiful city.

turns.speaker: EMILIE
turns.text: Should I stay?

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: It's up to you.

turns.speaker: GESTAPO
turns.text: Your friend Amon Goeth has been arrested.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: I'm sorry to hear that.

turns.speaker: GESTAPO
turns.text: There are some things that are unclear. We need to talk.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: I'd love to, it'll have to wait until I get back.  I have to leave.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: All right, okay, let's talk.

turns.speaker: GESTAPO
turns.text: In Breslau.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Breslau?  I can't go to Breslau.  Not now.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: We started without you.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: You know, they told me you were going to be trouble - Czurda and Scherner.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: You're kidding.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: He looks great, though, doesn't he? I have to know - where do you get a suit like that?  what is that, silk?  It's great.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: I'd say I'd get you one but the guy who made it, he's probably dead, I don't know.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: I go to work the other day, there's nobody there.  Nobody tells me about this, I have to find out, I have to go in, everybody's gone -

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: They're not gone, they're here.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: They're mine!

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Every day that goes by, I'm losing money. Every worker that is shot, costs me money - I have to get somebody else, I have to train them -

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: We're going to be making so much money, none of this is going to matter -

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: It's bad business.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: Some of the boys went crazy, what're you going to do?  You're right, it's bad business, but it's over with, it's done.  Occasionally, sure, okay, you got to make an example.  But that's good business.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: Scherner told me something else about you.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Yeah, what's that?

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: That you know the meaning of the word gratitude.  That it's not some vague thing with you like with some guys.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: True.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: Do you have any idea what's involved? The paperwork alone?  Forget you got to build it all, getting the fucking permits, that's enough to drive you crazy.  Then the engineers show up.  They stand around and they argue about drainage - I'm telling you, you'll want to shoot somebody, I've been through it, I know.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Well, you've been through it.  You know. You could make things easier for me.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: It's true.  Never happen in Cracow, though, we all love you too much.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: I pay you too much.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: You held back Stern.  You held back the one man most important to my business.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: He's important to my business.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: What do you want for him, I'll give it to you.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: I want him.  Come on, let's go inside, let's have a good time.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: I tried to call you, I'm running a little late, this is taking longer than I thought.  Have a drink.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: What's going on?

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: I got a shipment of Hungarians coming in, I got to make room for them.  It's always something.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: You took my workers.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: They're taking mine.  When I said they didn't have a future I didn't mean tomorrow.  Auschwitz.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: I don't know.  Soon.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: You want these people.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: These people, my people, I want my people.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: What are you, Moses?  What is this? Where's the money in this?  What's the scam?

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: It's good business.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: Oh, this is "good business" in your opinion. You've got to move them, the equipment, everything to Czechoslovakia - it doesn't make any sense.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Look -

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: You're not telling me something.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: It's good for me - I know them, I'm familiar with them.  It's good for you - you'll be compensated.  It's good for the Army.  You know what I'm going to make?  Artillery shells.  Tank shells. They need that.  Everybody's happy.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: Yeah, sure.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: If you admit to making three, then it's four, actually.  But how?

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: I just told you.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: You did, but you didn't.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: Yeah, all right, don't tell me, I'll go along with it, it's just irritating to me I can't figure it out.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: All you have to do is tell me what it's worth to you.  What's a person worth to you.

turns.speaker: GOETH
turns.text: Where are the guards?

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: The guards aren't allowed on the factory floor. They make my workers nervous.

turns.speaker: GOLDBERG
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: PFEFFERBERG
turns.text: You don't recognize it?  Maybe that's because it's not what I asked for.

turns.speaker: GOLDBERG
turns.text: You asked for shoe polish.

turns.speaker: PFEFFERBERG
turns.text: My buyers sold it to a guy who sold it to the Army.  But by the time it got there - because of the cold - it broke, the whole truckload.

turns.speaker: GOLDBERG
turns.text: So I'm responsible for the weather?

turns.speaker: PFEFFERBERG
turns.text: I asked for metal, you gave me glass.

turns.speaker: GOLDBERG
turns.text: This is not my problem.

turns.speaker: PFEFFERBERG
turns.text: Look it up.

turns.speaker: GOLDBERG
turns.text: Ghetto Police.  I'm a policeman now, can you believe it?

turns.speaker: PFEFFERBERG
turns.text: Yeah, I can.

turns.speaker: GOLDBERG
turns.text: Hey, Poldek, how's it going?  You know about the list?  You're on it.

turns.speaker: PFEFFERBERG
turns.text: Of course I'm on it.

turns.speaker: GOLDBERG
turns.text: You want to stay on it?  What do you got for me?

turns.speaker: PFEFFERBERG
turns.text: What do I got for you?

turns.speaker: GOLDBERG
turns.text: Takes diamonds to stay on this list.

turns.speaker: LOWENSTEIN
turns.text: I want to thank you, sir, for giving me the opportunity to work.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: You're welcome, I'm sure you're doing a great job.

turns.speaker: LOWENSTEIN
turns.text: The SS beat me up.  They would have killed me, but I'm essential to the war effort, thanks to you.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: That's great.

turns.speaker: LOWENSTEIN
turns.text: I work hard for you.  I'll continue to work hard for you.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: That's great, thanks.

turns.speaker: LOWENSTEIN
turns.text: God bless you, sir.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Yeah, okay.

turns.speaker: LOWENSTEIN
turns.text: You're a good man.

turns.speaker: PFEFFERBERG
turns.text: Like this?

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: There's nothing in the stores.

turns.speaker: PFEFFERBERG
turns.text: You have any idea what a shirt like this costs?

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Nice things cost money.

turns.speaker: PFEFFERBERG
turns.text: How many?

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: I don't know, ten or twelve.  That's a good color.  Dark blues, grays.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: How you feeling, all right?

turns.speaker: PFEFFERBERG
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: What's the matter, everything all right at home?  Mila's okay?

turns.speaker: PFEFFERBERG
turns.text: She's good.

turns.speaker: PFEFFERBERG
turns.text: What's wrong with it?

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: How should I know?  It's broken. See what you can do.

turns.speaker: PFEFFERBERG
turns.text: Good.  How's it going?

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Things are great, things are great.

turns.speaker: PFEFFERBERG
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: I'm having a drink, come on in, we'll have a drink.

turns.speaker: PFEFFERBERG
turns.text: I mean where have you been? Nobody's seen you around for a while.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: I've been here.  I guess I haven't been out.

turns.speaker: PFEFFERBERG
turns.text: I thought maybe you'd like to come over, have some dinner, some of the people are coming over.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Yeah?  Yeah, that'd be nice, let me get my coat.

turns.speaker: RASCH
turns.text: Oskar, good of you to come.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Are you kidding, I never miss a party. Police Chief Rasch, my wife Emilie.

turns.speaker: RASCH
turns.text: How do you do?

turns.speaker: RASCH
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: I need a drink.

turns.speaker: RASCH
turns.text: Oh, God, you don't have a drink?

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Wine?

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: One of these days the Russians are going to show up unannounced at my gate.  I'd like the chance to defend myself.  I'd like my wife to have that chance.  My civilian engineers. My secretary.

turns.speaker: RASCH
turns.text: We're losing the war, aren't we.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: It kind of looks that way.

turns.speaker: RASCH
turns.text: Pistols?

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Pistols, rifles, carbines ...  I'd be grateful.

turns.speaker: SCHERNER
turns.text: I'd never ask you for money, you know that. I don't even like talking about it - money, favors - I find it very awkward, it makes me very uncomfortable -

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: No, look.  It's the others.  They're the ones causing these delays.

turns.speaker: SCHERNER
turns.text: What others?

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Whoever.  They're the ones.  They'd appreciate some kind of gesture from me.

turns.speaker: SCHERNER
turns.text: That'd be fine.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Done.  Lets not talk about it anymore, let's have a good time.

turns.speaker: SCHERNER
turns.text: The place produces nothing.  I shouldn't say that - nothing it produces reaches the Army.  That's not all right.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: So I'll talk to him about it.

turns.speaker: SCHERNER
turns.text: He's a friend of yours, you want to help him out. Tell me this, though - has he ever once shown you his appreciation?  I've yet to see it. Never a courtesy.  Never a thank you note.  He forgets my wife at Christmas time -

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: He's got no style, we all know that. So, we should hang him for it?

turns.speaker: SCHERNER
turns.text: He doesn't deserve your loyalty.  More important, he's not worth you making threats against us.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Did I threaten anybody here?  I stated a simple fact.

turns.speaker: STERN
turns.text: I was just the accountant.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Simple engineering, though, wouldn't you think?  Change the machines around, whatever you do, you could make other things, couldn't you?

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Once the war ends, forget it, but for now it's great, you could make a fortune. Don't you think?

turns.speaker: STERN
turns.text: I think most people right now have other priorities.

turns.speaker: STERN
turns.text: Get the contracts and I'm sure you'll do very well.  In fact the worse things get the better you'll do.  It was a "pleasure."

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: The contracts?  That's the easy part. Finding the money to buy the company, that's hard.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Jews, yeah.  Investors.

turns.speaker: STERN
turns.text: Jews can no longer own businesses, sir, that's why this one's for sale.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Well, they wouldn't own it, I'd own it. I'd pay them back in product.  They can trade it on the black market, do whatever they want, everybody's happy.

turns.speaker: STERN
turns.text: Pots and pans.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Something they can hold in their hands.

turns.speaker: STERN
turns.text: I don't know anybody who'd be interested in that.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: They should be.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: What was that about the SS, the rate, the ... ?

turns.speaker: STERN
turns.text: The Jewish worker's salary, you pay it directly to the SS, not to the worker. He gets nothing.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: But it's less.  It's less than what I would pay a Pole.  That's the point I'm trying to make.  Poles cost more.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: I could try to read this or I could eat my lunch while it's till hot.  We're doing well?

turns.speaker: STERN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Better this month than last?

turns.speaker: STERN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Any reason to think next month will be worse?

turns.speaker: STERN
turns.text: The war could end.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: STERN
turns.text: There's a machinist outside who'd like to thank you personally for giving him a job.

turns.speaker: SCHINDLER
turns.text: Don't ever do that to me again.

turns.speaker: STERN
turns.text: Do what?
